title: Justin MacFarlane riverside copy of justin & michail   apr 9, 2025 001 deep dives

rawLines.text: Hey, welcome to the Deconstructor of Fun
podcast. I'm your host, Mishki Katcooff,
and my guest today is Justin McFarland.
In this episode, we talk about what does
it really take to go from a 3D artist to
a general manager of a billion-dollar
game. So Justin McFarland, general
manager of this say game, shares how
staying put and stepping up turned
Jackpot Party Casino into a top grossing
powerhouse. It's a story of trust,
intuition, and the kind of leadership
that only comes from doing the work.
Now, without further ado, ladies and
gentlemen, Justin McFarland.
Josh McFarland. McFarland. McFarland
podcast. Thank you. Thank you. That's a
powerful name. Scottish. Scott. Yeah.
Thank you. I appreciate it.
So, so you're a GM of Jackpot Party
Casino. That's right. A pretty big game.
Uh, but I'd love to talk about that. I'd
love to talk about how you became a
general manager. Have you worked at at
site site play for 17 years? I'd like to
talk about live ops. I'd like to talk
about how you introduce complex features
to casual audiences. But what I really
want to start this off with is in the
pre-recording. Mhm. You're you're taking
this podcast from Cedar Falls. Yes.
Which for the unknown audience in
everywhere is is a 40,000 person town in
Midwest. Yeah, Iowa. And which actually
you might even have to explain to the
viewers where Iowa is at in the middle.
Right in the middle. Listen, they
wouldn't know what De Moines is or where
that that would which is a capital of
Iowa. Anyways, but you previously had
your
team partly in Austin, which everybody
knows, and in Cedar Falls, which nobody
knows. And then you made certain
decisions uh as of late. And I would
like if you're able to talk about those.
Yeah. Uh well, Cedar Falls has been um
for me where I like I've grown at the
company is it's it's been the studio
where social gaming for Sciplay really
started off. Um it's where Jackpot Party
was founded, which a lot of people don't
know. It's where we built the team
originally. It's where we first launched
the product. Um and what happened was
throughout COVID, um we've expanded the
company multiple over the the last
decade. Uh going into Austin, Texas,
going to Tel Viv Israel. We're trying to
bring in product knowledge to Jackpot
Party. We're trying to bring more
experts um to the game team. And so we
allowed ourselves to kind of, you know,
lean into the remote working as it
became a little bit more prominent in
the industry. And so we did that
probably in 2020, 2021. We started
adding and it started small, one or two
people. I think uh Daphna was was the
first as as director of monetization. We
kind of built that around her. Um and
then we built even more up over the
years. And suddenly, you know, we got to
a situation where I don't think it was
very strategic. It was more every hire
we did was an opportunity hire. We're
looking to bring somebody into the
company. Um, and suddenly we had about
20 people. Our entire product team, our
entire analytics team was in Austin. And
our entire development studio, some of
the people that I've worked with my
entire career that I, you know, a lot of
my success I I dictate like around like
Michael Gasman who is our director of
engineering is based out of Cedar Falls,
Iowa. So you have the development team
here in Cedar Falls, Iowa where it's
always been and suddenly we had this
product and analytics team in Austin,
Texas. Um, which was great for the time.
We were making we were doing what a lot
of companies were doing co co just
making it work. And you know we thought
there was this illusion that it was it
was something that was okay. It was all
right conditions. We were able to use
technology to be have able to have video
calls having conversations like you and
I are having right now. Like it was
feasible. It was something that was
sustainable. But as we started to kind
of go throughout the years and we
started to run into challenges as a game
team, that's where we started to see
kind of the cracks in the foundations.
And really for me, like what the biggest
thing that I saw was honestly some of
the engagement scores like and uh we do
engagement scores at Scipplay where our
employees voice is very important to us.
Um we have them write comments. Uh SGM I
I take those things very seriously. I
read every single comment. Uh sometimes
it's a depressing read. If you ever re
read the reviews of games, reading the
uh the engagement scores of a game team,
it's very similar where like you read
everything and you just kind of put the
ego off to the side. And some of the
stuff that I saw as I was reading those
was just, you know, it was not just
about the struggles the team was having,
the struggles of process, the struggles
of lack of planning, stuff I've seen
throughout decades, solvable problems.
The things that I was seeing was like
the the lack of understanding of the
vision, the lack of the context of the
decisions we were making and that was
starting to show itself in the product
that we were shipping. Um, as a as a GM,
I'm a huge advocate like the product is
a reflection of the environment it's
built in. It's a reflection of the
chemistry as a team you have working
together. And you are starting to see
that disconnect not only in the product
itself but in some of the strategies and
then you certainly see it in the morale
of the team and the understanding and
just the overall engagement. And what
was missing was really that just the
thing I love about making games in the
first place. It's just that connection
working with people and uh and and that
spirit of collaboration that it takes
like because it's it's making games.
It's creative. It's collaborative. It's
it's whiteboards. It's standing up. It's
it's it's energy. It's all that stuff
that goes into games. And that fourth
wall of trying to get people to work
together was just a huge barrier. So, it
was we made the decision in December.
And uh it's kind of ironic because I'm
talking to you in a temporary office as
we invest in in the new studio and
remodel in it. Like the environment is a
reflection of where we're at as a game
team because it's very much rebuilding
for for the team on Jackpot Party. bring
in members from Austin Tech and asking
our product team members to relocate
from Austin. Um, which is a really
really tough choice for a lot of those
people and some of the people uh who
weren't able to do it. We made the hard
choice of prioritizing the team over
individuals and so that meant bringing
new leadership in and moving on from
some leadership because we said we want
people together. You know, one of the
things that we believe in at Scyplay is
playing together, and playing together
is what helps drive great gameplay. And
so, we made the tough decision to move
on. So, we're we're bringing building a
new leadership team on the game. Um,
we're renovating the office space. Like,
so there's a lot going on right now, I
guess, is is kind of where you're going
at with the question, I should say.
Yeah. So, basically, it's not that you
went to return to office from work from
home, right? You went all the way from
working at two locations to actually
choosing one location and choosing the u
how would I put it? The less popular
one. Yeah. Which is of course compared
to to an Austin. You talked about the
engagement scores uh that that led to
your decision. Was there any business
decision behind it? Because like let's
put it this way. It's a it's not an easy
decision to make especially since you've
accumulated certain type of a talent
that is probably on the data and product
side that is um usually MBAs or or
others that are quite often in the big
cities and not so much in the smaller
towns. How did you how did you make that
decision? Was it was it was it the game
performance or was it the the engagement
scores and sort of intangibles and how
you felt that you need to organize the
team to be more successful? I think it
was uh you know there's a lot of like
data points like a lot of team members
we have a really really strong
production staff that leans into like
production data. So you can you can see
in stuff like in terms of like the gaps
in even just like work getting completed
and like the the time between stuff. So
there is certainly an element of that
type of data, but I have to say the
intangibles, the feeling is really what
drove it and really supporting the
development team. You know, that, you
know, the art team that's in Cedar Falls
already, the existing talent that we've
built over the years um and probably
adapting, at least from our standpoint,
maybe this is a little bit egotistical,
but uh it it's what Phantom or Sciplay
has done for years. like for 15 years
we've brought people who haven't had
necessarily experiment experience in the
game industry but they had passion and
they had raw talent and they had drive
and that's what like as a business it's
like let's get back to what was growing
talent what worked for us 15 years ago
what worked with us a decade ago um and
stop trying to chase like you know the
people who have h been in the industry
for 10 15 years so prioritize and build
an environment of people who want to
come to Cedar Falls and I'll be honest
the people who come to Cedar Falls who
are willing to take that jump are
committed. They're coming for the right
reasons. They're coming because they
want to make an impact on a great
product and I think that helps us find
the people who are really in it uh to to
make a difference on the game level. So,
um it was definitely more intuition, it
was definitely more feeling um but a
little bit of experience of what we've
seen that has worked for us as a company
for so long. and talking about making
this type of a decision like let's uh
let me put myself in the let's say
Josh's so your
CEOs the shoes or boats
um he's he's hearing this so one of his
top titles and top GMs wants to totally
restructure the team and it's really
based on a strong gut feeling that this
could work better if we were just all in
the same place. restructuring of this
team means losing critical talent in
data and product, but you believe that
you're able to rebuild the team in Cedar
Falls. Um, and for for a while you'll be
under
underm. And we're talking about big live
op game that probably makes, you know,
plus hund00 million a year. Um, that's a
pretty big decision. How, tell me, how
does this type of a conversation goes?
Uh well, I'm really really fortunate.
You've had a number of conversation with
Josh. Uh he is he is a huge strong
supporter. Um and he's very quick to
understand the problems that you're
trying to solve. That's one of the
things he excels at is solving problems.
So he could see um he's very logic
based. So when we sat down and had the
conversation, he understand understood
pretty quickly the problems we're
facing. Understood and believes in what
has worked for us historically as a
company and absolutely is a huge
proponent of trying to build talent, you
know, from the ground up from within
rather than trying to hire talent. So he
saw it pretty quickly. For me, that
conversation was relatively easy. It was
a scary conversation. Um, and you know,
there's a number of people involved in
those. you know, Destri, I don't know if
you've had the the privilege to talk to,
he's always somebody who is he he looks
at every single angle at at CYplay. He's
kind of our our risk guy because he
could just see where problems can
emerge. So, of course, he's sitting in
the chair and saying this is insanity.
This is this is this is not going to
work. And uh and then we got that group
aligned. Uh Cameron was aligned. There's
just a lot of support um for what it
could be. And they understood that what
we could what we were doing was working.
I think that was the thing that we we
sat in a room. We said to one another,
it it was a very much similar to this.
There's couches and we're just having a
very very low-key conversation and we're
saying what we're doing could work. We
could just keep doing this and it will
be fine. We will probably be able to run
the business. We will be able to grow.
We'll be able to grow the game. It will
never be great. It will never have the
culture that we want to have on a game
team because it's missing the component
of being together. And the second I
think we stood and said that statement
that said we'll be good, we'll be okay,
but we won't be great. Every new one
knew it was the right choice in that
room. They knew there was going to be a
number of challenges. They knew it was
going to be a ton of work and all of us
were probably going to have to pitch
into your point because we're going to
be understaffed in some areas. We're
we're definitely going to have a lack of
experience. I'm not going to lie, Josh
is is helping out right now at the on
the game team level. He's helping with
the strategy. We're like working
together. So everybody's doing more
their fair share, but everybody
understands the vision of what we're
trying to build together. Um, that
conversation went really well. And then
obviously we have to go into the
boardroom and have a larger conversation
and there's certainly a number of facial
expressions that this is a huge risk for
the company. It's one of the company's
biggest titles, the biggest title in in
the company. And so as a business, yeah,
it's there's a lot of different angles
to consider, but it got back to that
statement of can we be good? Will this
be okay? Yes. Will it be great? Probably
not. At least we didn't believe it. And
so once we answered that aligned on that
statement, everybody knew it was the
right way to go forward. So that's uh it
must be pretty empowering to be able to
make such a such a decision where where
it's not a business decision that is
very easy to get through like hey we
invest this we get this back I made all
the calculations our team is ready let's
go um but it's a gut feeling decision
that that you are making that has an
impact on the biggest product in the
company's portfolio
um talk me about how did you talk to the
team about this because I think that's
the most difficult conversation you have
to have. So for like there was a lot of
conversations with the team that
happened leading up to that like that's
what helped kind of lead that like you
know you go into the engagement scores
you hear the voices and then you have
one-on- ones with like everybody on the
team. You you know that's that's one of
the most important things I can do is
listen to my team as GM. It's probably
the most important thing I do. Uh, and
so having those conversations, that's
where you get the confidence that's less
about your gut and more about just
hearing what's right for the team and a
reflection of what you hear out and and
see from from interacting with them. Um,
so for the team members in Cedar Falls
knowing that we're going to continue
invested in that studio, it's great
news. They're excited. Uh, and it's what
they've been asking for. It's what they
want that that confidence. It's they
want that connection. They want to get
back to where it was everybody under one
roof working together. And you see it
every time we'd have people in town
visiting. Like that's the comment that
always come up for. Obviously there's
there's a different side of that story
where you're going with people who have
been remote for the past 5 years. Uh not
fun conversations. Um and those are
tough because you know they can't
understand it. It's it's not something
that that works for them. And and for
some people personally they couldn't
make the move. And these are incredibly
talented people. like they're not just
people who are, you know, ah it's okay,
we don't mind losing them. Some of these
people are really, really good at what
they do. Um, and you just try to explain
it to them as best as possible. You try
to un, you know, you admit that they're
probably never going to understand from
their perspective the decision.
Certainly probably not going to agree
with it. Um, but out of respect, you
just say we think this is right for the
business and these are the reasons why
and you know and and we'll either invite
you to come relocate to Cedar Falls or
we'll treat you as respectfully as a kid
and we we I think as as a company we did
a really good job of just you know
working with those people to find them
either new positions within the company
or really good packages to help them get
them back on their feet somewhere in the
industry. Continue helping them find new
roles wherever we can.
And how did you have the conversation
without leading them to kind of telling
you the story that you want to hear
basically that that they want to all
work from the same location rather than
um with in two locations and remotely.
Yeah. Well, that is a little bit
challenging to not lead somebody when
you're when you're having that
conversation. I think naturally it's
like uh you want to be able to like
you're looking to hear that answer. you
want. That's why I'm I'm terrible at
like running focus group sessions
because I just want to tell the player,
hey, don't you think this feature is
awesome? Um, but you just try to resist
it. And for me, I think the biggest
thing I try to do is just just listen
first and and not talk. And that's the
best way to chin grock. Like what is
that person's perspective? What do they
think? Um, and didn't ask situ like
didn't ask specific questions like what
do you think about like should we all be
in one studio? Ask questions like what
are the problems we're facing? What are
the challenges you face as an
individual? Like how are what could we
do to make your job better? What you
could we do to make this game more
successful? And then just let the person
go on from there. And it was surprising
how so many different people would kind
of they wouldn't say it directly, but it
would be the the roundabout like, well,
you know, there's gaps. It's hard to get
a hold of people. It's it's challenging
to understand what somebody's saying
when they they type it in Slack, which
when you're remote, text communication
becomes such like a big part of how
people interact with one another. And uh
personally, I hate texting. I'm terrible
at it. I get, you know, the tone is
lost, the the verb non-verbal cues, all
of that stuff. And so there's that extra
layer of communication that just adds a
little bit of thrash. And people would
bring that up all the time. you would
have all of these, you know, uh,
disagreements between people. People
weren't aligned. They didn't understand
the vision of what we were trying to do
or what one product managers was pushing
to try to achieve some sort of results
because it was all done through
interpretation. And they wouldn't
directly say it, but the answer in every
single conversation was like right in
front of your face. It's like there's
this elephant in the room that nobody's
addressing that there's six states
between us, or I'm going to be wrong in
the geography, so we might have to edit
that. I don't know how many states are
between Iowa and Texas. I think it's
three. Uh miles, hundreds of miles
between us. And it's like and that would
nobody would come out and say that, but
everybody would allude to it in those
conversations. And you know, you try to
resist putting words in people's mouth,
but I would just sit down and have
conversation after conversation and I
would hear the same answer in different
types of responses. And as I had all of
those one-on- ones and as I had all of
those roundt discussions and all of
those time with all that time spent with
the team, it became more and more
increasingly obvious, I I gained a lot
of confidence that it was the right
decision through all of those. And
that's I think that's how I interpreted
and got that confidence that it was the
right call to make. And and now you're
in a stage where you've changed the uh
the locations. You're integrating your
team to work out of Cedar Falls. How did
you manage to do this transition and how
did you manage to keep the business up
and going and growing?
It's a little
rocky I'll tell you uh as good as we
could. Um you know because at that same
point you know you're transition you're
identifying who is going to be able to
make that jump. So you have to answer
who is going to be a part of the team uh
and then you have to continue to run the
business in the short term. Um we just
fortunate a couple of the members
actually yesterday was their first day
in office and it was it was like the
payoff the reward was right there like
you saw it you saw everybody like like
literally like high-fiving hugging happy
to be together being one another. Um but
how we try to manage this we we try to
say hey we've come out and said that's
important for people to work together.
People obviously can't move in a day in
a week. We have to have a an onboarding
process. So, we try to get people to
come up and visit at least a couple
times for a weekend and to start that
process. Um, once we knew who was was
part of the long-term team, uh, we knew
who we are going to start investing in,
who we're going to start building this
team around. Uh, and then we also have
to have the process of sourcing out, you
know, the people backbone. Um, so in
that gap, we actually had to cover down.
That's where I kind of talked a little
bit earlier that Josh is actually
Jackpot Party's director of monetization
and product right now, which is a uh
it's a interesting position. He's
managing as good as he can. Uh and you
know, really just kind of leaning on the
team members that that are going to be
here for the long term. you know, the
the Josh Malins, the the Sapnas who were
willing to take that jump, relocate,
like you said, like a city of Austin,
Texas to, you know, someone of that age
who's this giant vibrant studio like
they're they're invested in their
careers, they're invested in the team,
they're taking, you know, they're
committing to the long term. And so
trying to work with them to try to build
them up, make sure that they're
empowered, and most importantly, make
sure that they're connected with the
team as well as possible. do that
through having them visit as much as
possible and now we're we're starting to
embrace them with them just kind of move
into the studio. Um, with that there was
a lot of just, okay, this is a new
leadership group that we're building.
This is a new game team. We have to run
the dayto-day. So, there's some things
that we have to do.
probably doing that a little bit more
top down in terms of the strategies that
we're putting out, in terms of the
decisions that we're making, but it's a
good opportunity for us to just look at
all of our processes, all of the things
we do as a game team, and just
re-evaluate like is that the right way
for us to do it. We're talking about
things like, you know, how do we build
our live ops calendar? Who what do those
those phases look like? Um are they as
efficient as they could be? Do they
serve a purpose? Do they serve the team?
Um, so there was a lot of just kind of
rebuilding some of those processes just
because it's different people who are
going to be involved with the process
and people have different, you know,
expertise. They have different ways that
they want to do things. And so like just
like any game team, when you're coming
to a studio, you don't try to come in
there with your your certain ways of
that you're going to do something. This
is my methodology. This is the only way
I operate. You try to listen to the team
and and and develop a process around
them for what works for them. And so
that's kind of what we've been doing
over pretty much the last, you know, two
to three months. Meanwhile, uh,
overhauling the games economy and doing
things like you said, like running the
game on a day-to-day basis. So, it's,
uh, it's been a wild ride. Yeah, I think
it's just a really fascinating to talk
about the details of of, you know, top
grossing game really changing the way
they are operating as a team, relocating
people from from drastically different
city to another town. And how are you
able to keep the operations up and going
while acting in the way that you believe
needs to be or operating in a way that
you believe needs to be operated even
though it's not clear on the business
perspective on the number side that this
is something you have to do. Um, another
thing that I really wanted to hear from
you is like how come you've been at
Scyplay for 17 years? That's not normal.
All
right. Uh yeah, I kind of I I started
talking about that a lot of the time and
this is um you know I I graduated from
Fullale University so I always uh go
back there every like six months. It's a
it's a gaming school in Winter Park,
Florida. Uh and you know they asked me
to you know talk to some of the students
and you know my presentation is usually
like an unexpected journey. That's
probably if I had an autobiography that
would be it. Um, you know, I you know, I
started in art and UI design, 3D
modeling. That's it's probably not a
consistent GM path to to be honest. And
if you would have told me I would have
been at slots for 17 years, I would have
said I would not have expected to do
that. Um, basically, you know, I was
going to school for fine art when I was
at the University of Northern Iowa for a
year and um, everybody had a lot of free
time your freshman year in college, so
everybody had their own hobbies. Uh I
watched basically a lot of DVDs that my
old joke is that they I used we used to
have movies on these things called disc
and they always came with like special
features of like behind the scenes and
as I watched more and more of those I
became super super fascinated about the
process of making something enter like
entertainment based whether it's games
or films and all the different people it
took to make that type of stuff go from
a vision to reality and like and like
you watch like Lord of the Rings has an
amazing in like 16 hours of behind the
scenes where they show like even the
people whose job was to hand make the
chain mail that the actors wrote and
you're just like that many people
believed in a project like they poured
their heart and soul what an awesome
life like what an amazing ability to do
that and so that's why I went to Fullale
because I just wanted to be a part of
that I wanted to be working in games and
films work on something I was proud of
and once I graduated I moved back home
and I started shipping out my demo reel
to different studios across the world
looking for that first gig. And by
chance I found at the time what was
called Family Effects, which was a small
game studio that uh basically made at
the time they made slot games that were
just sold brick and mortar stores like
at Walmart for like $20. It wasn't free
to play, wasn't mobile. Mobile games
weren't even a thing. This was back in
2008, so it was a long time. And so I
was brought in basically to do UI work
to help do menu design um and art
background. Um, but I'm the type of
individual I love to learn. I love
challenges. I love that. That's what's
rewarding to me is trying to do new
things. And so, um, when I was working
at the studio, one, I just love the
people. So, when you love the people you
work with, you that's the number one
thing. It's it's going to be always hard
to leave a place like that because you
you learn to work with different people.
And two, this was right around the time
that the studio was explored and doing
new things. And one of those new things
was was uh Facebook gaming at the time.
Like somebody like Josh was on the
podcast. I don't know if he's ever told
the story uh about how we built Jackpot
Party, but it was literally like three
guys. Uh I was brought into DU UI at the
time and and Art uh we had an engineer
whose name is Forest Stow. He's now the
CTO of the company and Josh was
effectively our product manager at the
time. And uh we saw a game had a game on
Facebook. It was using Unity and we just
said, "Hey, can we can we put it on? Can
we do that?" And I'm I'm really
shortening the story. Obviously, there's
a lot of details that I I don't want to
leave out or anything like that, but it
there was no expectations with that
project. It was just trying something
new and and obviously it became
something that blew up. And I I kind of
love to tell the story where like
everybody's celebrating around the DAU,
the revenue, how quickly the game is
getting adopted. Meanwhile, poor Forest
is having like a like a meltdown because
he's trying to build this server
architecture on the fly. And it turned
into something that nobody really
expected. And I think the reason I tell
that story is because that's what I love
about the company. It's always never
been afraid to try new things. It's
never been afraid to innovate. And so my
growth is a reflection of the company's
growth because it's always been an
opportunity as if you're the right
person with the the right passion and
